bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Hugh S. Cumming, October 15, 1925

div1.p: Carter refutes Ravenel's suggestion that Henry Rose Carter did not influence Reed's decision to investigate the theory of mosquito transmission of yellow fever and encloses documents to support this position.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Hugh S. Cumming, October 15, 1925
div1.opener:
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
October 15, 1925.
Surgeon General H. S. Cumming,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Cumming:
div1.p:
Your letter of October 14, 1925, enclosing that of Dr. Mazyck
Ravenel, has just reached me.

1: A carbon of a letter of Walter Reed to Father (original
in my possession) in which he states that Father's work “did more to
impress” him “with the importance of an intermediate host than every-
thing else put to-gether”.

2: Transcription, from stenographic notes taken at the time, of
part of a talk Father had with Thayer and Parker one Sunday afternoon in July
1924, just before we left for the Jamaica Conference.

As you know Father was very loath to talk of the influence of
his work in determining the direction of the experiments of the Reed
Board. Indeed, I tried vainly several times to get him to dictate or
write out in detail the happenings in Cuba, but he replied that “the
only allowable ambition for a man was the ambition of achievement” and
that it didn't matter who got the credit so long as the work was done.
done.
-2-
He further told me that he was rather glad that he would probably die be-
fore he got to the Section of his History of Yellow Fever dealing with the
discovery of the method of transmission of yellow fever as if he did so
he would have to claim credit for “determining the direction of Reed's work”
for whileSince for although Reed himself, both in personal letters and in some of his earlier
(“preliminary”) announcements freely and whole-heartedly admitted this, yet
it iswas one thing to have the value of one's work admitted by the fellow
scientist to whom it had shown the way and another to claim that credit for
oneself--even when possessing, as I consider we do, data to prove it.

It was just by good luck then that one Sunday afternoon, shortly
before we left for Jamaica last year, that Dr. Thayer and Dr. Parker (both
old and trusted friends) spent most of the afternoon with him and, in the
enthusiasm engendered by a long talk between the three on yellow fever, he
gave the details herein enclosed. As soon as he started, I slipped quietly
behind the head of his bed (where he couldn't see what I was doing!) and,
with an understanding glance at the other two, opened my stenographic note
book and began to record the conversation. Not, of course, with any idea
of publication, but because I wanted the exact data for “the family ar-
chives.” There are gaps, as I had to get up to answer the telephone etc.
once or twice and, of course, he kept on talking. Indeed, had he known
what I was doing he would have stopped his narrative--or have stopped me!

I am sure Dr. Thayer will gladly vouch for the accuracy of the
statements in Enclosure B, of this letter although, of course, he couldn't swear to the
identical words of the parts in quotation marks. I can assure you, however,
that they are as Father spoke them.

3: No one was more keenly desireous that Finlay be accorded the honor
justly due him than Father. He both loved and revered the Great Cuban--
“nomen clarum et venerabile!” as he nearly always added afterwhen mentioning
hism name. Indeed, when Father was asked to write the Section on Yellow Fever
Fever
-3-
in The Practice of Medicine in the Tropics (Oxford Press:London, 1922) he
made it an absolute condition of so doing that they should waive their request
that no historical data be incorporated in the article in order that he be
allowed to pay proper tribute to Finlay. This, Colonel Byam agreed to, and
I am enclosing a copy of the paragraphs (from the 1922 edition) treating of
Finlay's work and comparing it with that of Beauperthuy and Nott.

I most heartily concur in Dr. Ravenel's statement that “the truth of
medical history” is of more value than the credit given “any one particular
man.” Indeed, the two things are not comparable. I feel sure, however, for
this very reason, that he will be glad to have this additional light one the sub-
ject, since, from what I have often heard of him from Father, as well as
from his universal reputation for ability and fair-mindedness it will
be a satisfaction to him to render justice where justice is due.

I have more data on this subject, but I have gotten out of bed to
collect this and, unless you find it insufficient, I will let the rest
alone until I am convalescent at any rate, since I think what I am enclosing
is sufficiently convincing of the fact that Father's work did “determine
the direction of Reed's work” and that soReed admitted it.
div1.closer:
With hopes that what I am enclosing may be what you wish,
Most truly yours, L. A. Carter Enclosures
